name: Jim Winterberger
title: Founder, Head of Growth & Government Relations, President

flow.context: Jim Winterberger is the Founder and President of Tahoe Getaways — 200–350+ vacation rental homes in North Lake Tahoe/Truckee, operating since 2001. He also carries the title Head of Growth & Government Relations, meaning he owns brand reputation, owner retention, and regulatory compliance. No inspection or ops tech platform was found publicly — they likely run manual processes across the entire portfolio. Local competitor Lake Tahoe Accommodations (100+ units) already uses Breezeway. Sam's angle: works with similar vacation rental operators in mountain markets and was just skiing Jackson Hole — he knows this world firsthand.

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper.say: Hey, could you get me through to Jim? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: Keep it short and confident. Don't explain what it's about. Sound like you know him. If Jim picks up directly, skip to the opener.

branches.label: Jim picks up or they transfer you

gatekeeper_pushback.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_pushback.say: Yeah — I work with a few other property managers up in the Tahoe area. Would you mind letting him know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_pushback.note: Still don't pitch. Just dose a little context. Keep it casual and redirect with the ask.

branches.label: They press harder or ask for more

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Sure thing — we help a couple other vacation rental companies with their inspection workflows. I sent Jim a note already — would you mind giving him a heads up that I'm on the line?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: This is your last gatekeeper move. If this doesn't work, pivot to getting a callback time or ask if Abigail Shea on the ops team is available.

gatekeeper_blocked.label: GATEKEEPER — BLOCKED
gatekeeper_blocked.say: No worries at all. Would it be possible to leave him a voicemail? And when's usually the best time to catch him — mornings or afternoons?
gatekeeper_blocked.note: Get callback timing intel. If they mention someone else on the ops side, you know Abigail Shea is Operations Manager — ask for her by name. Don't burn the gatekeeper relationship.

branches.label: They give callback time or voicemail
They suggest someone else or the ops team

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Jim — I work with a few other vacation rental managers up in the Tahoe area on their turnover and inspection workflows. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Slow down. Smile. Feet-up-on-the-desk energy. Pause after 'tossed around' and let him respond. Don't rush into a pitch.

branches.label: Yes / maybe he's heard of you

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone in your shoes on the inspection side. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let him talk. Whatever he says, bridge into discovery or the pain trigger depending on how much he already knows.

branches.label: He shares what he heard or is curious
He's vague or doesn't remember details

heard_no_pain.label: HAVEN'T HEARD — PAIN TRIGGER
heard_no_pain.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call — I've been working with another PM company, pretty similar setup to you guys — big portfolio, high-end mountain homes — and the thing that kept eating them alive was this gap between what their cleaning team reported as ready and what the home actually looked like when someone walked in. They were getting owners calling about damage from two guests ago that nobody caught, and every time it turned into a fight over whose deposit should've covered it. With 200-plus homes, I figured that might ring a bell?
heard_no_pain.note: PAUSE after 'ring a bell.' Do NOT keep talking. Let Jim react. The specificity of 200-plus homes and the deposit dispute story should hit a nerve for a founder who's accountable to property owners.

branches.label: That resonates — 'Yeah we deal with that'

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? I'm usually pretty quick.
bad_timing.note: Don't push. Respect the timing. But try to lock a specific day and window.

branches.label: He gives a time or says try again

bad_timing_lock.label: LOCK CALLBACK TIME
bad_timing_lock.say: Perfect — I've got Thursday morning pulled up. How does 10 AM Pacific look? I'll keep it to five minutes, promise.
bad_timing_lock.note: Pick a specific day and time. Make it easy to say yes. If he counters with another time, take whatever he offers.

branches.label: He agrees to a callback time

who_is_this.label: CONFUSED OR SUSPICIOUS
who_is_this.say: Yeah totally fair — it is a cold call, I'll be honest. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? And you can totally hang up on me if it doesn't click.
who_is_this.note: Disarm with honesty. The 30-second permission ask lowers the stakes. If he says yes, go straight to the pain trigger.

branches.label: He says no or starts to hang up

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot — totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't interesting?
permission_rejected.note: This split gives him two options. 'Horrible time' reopens the door for a callback. 'Not interesting' lets you understand the real issue and exit gracefully.

branches.label: Bad timing — open to a callback
He pauses or softens a little

pain_positive.label: PAIN LANDS — HE ENGAGES
pain_positive.say: Yeah — that's exactly what I keep hearing. So what does your inspection process actually look like right now? Are your cleaners taking photos after turnovers, or is it more of a spot-check situation?
pain_positive.note: STOP PITCHING. He's warm. Ask questions. Learn his current process. You want to find out: (1) are cleaners taking photos, (2) who reviews them, (3) what falls through the cracks. His answers shape how you position RapidEye.

branches.label: He asks what you actually do
He says Abigail or the ops team handles that

pain_neutral.label: LUKEWARM — CURIOUS BUT GUARDED
pain_neutral.say: Totally fair — I know that's a bold claim from a stranger on the phone. In a nutshell, we built an AI that analyzes the turnover photos your team's already taking and flags damage, missing items, staging issues — automatically. Plugs right into whatever system you're already using. No workflow change at all. Would you be open to taking a look when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
pain_neutral.note: He needs a reason to stay on the line. Give the one-sentence solution and the low-friction CTA. Don't over-explain. Pause and let him respond.

branches.label: Agrees to a meeting or says send something

discovery.label: DISCOVERY — ASK QUESTIONS
discovery.say: I appreciate you walking me through that. So when a turnover happens — who's actually reviewing the photos, if anyone? And what happens when something gets missed and an owner finds out about it?
discovery.note: Dig into the pain. Uncover: (1) their photo review process or lack thereof, (2) how damage disputes get handled, (3) how often things slip through. If he mentions Abigail Shea running ops, she's your internal champion for next steps.

branches.label: He shares details and is engaged
He says ops team handles it, not his area
He asks how you'd solve this

discovery_deep.label: DEEPER DISCOVERY
discovery_deep.say: That makes a lot of sense. And with Tahoe being the market it is — high-value homes, owners who expect everything to be perfect — I'm curious, what's been the biggest headache heading into this year? Is it more the growth side or keeping quality locked down across the whole portfolio?
discovery_deep.note: You're building the business case now. If he mentions regulatory pressure or compliance (his title includes Government Relations), pivot to the documentation angle. If he mentions growth, position RapidEye as something that scales without adding headcount.

regulatory_angle.label: REGULATORY AND COMPLIANCE ANGLE
regulatory_angle.say: Yeah — I saw the whole Measure T situation and the new STR ordinance from last year. A few managers I've talked to said the documentation and compliance side has gotten way more intense. One thing that's been landing really well is that every turnover now has a timestamped, AI-verified record of the home's condition — basically an automatic paper trail that shows exactly what it looked like before and after every stay. That piece alone has been huge for the folks dealing with enforcement scrutiny. Would it make sense to show you how that works?
regulatory_angle.note: Jim literally carries the title 'Head of Government Relations.' If he brought up regulation or compliance, this is your tailored value prop. Don't overdo it — let him connect the dots to his own situation.

branches.label: That resonates — wants to learn more
Interesting but not a priority right now

solution_pitch.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
solution_pitch.say: So what we built — in a nutshell — is an AI that plugs into whatever system your cleaners already use to take photos after turnovers. It automatically scans every image and flags damage, missing items, staging problems — anything that's off. Your team doesn't change a single thing about their workflow. They take photos like they normally would, and RapidEye catches what human eyes miss across 200-plus homes.
solution_pitch.note: One clear explanation, then move to the CTA. Don't go deeper into features unless he asks. If he mentions a specific PMS or tool, note it for the demo.

branches.label: Intrigued or wants to see it
'We already have a process for that'

cta_meeting.label: ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Would you be open to taking a look — even just 20 minutes? I can show you what it actually catches on real turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas from what other Tahoe managers are doing and we part as friends.
cta_meeting.note: Low-friction CTA. 'Worst case you steal some ideas' lowers the commitment. If he says yes, immediately lock in a specific time. Don't leave it open-ended.

branches.label: Not right now or no budget
Have someone else on my team look at this

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday pulled up — what works better for you? I can do mornings or afternoons.
book_meeting.note: Lock a specific day and time NOW. Don't leave it open-ended. Plan to send the calendar invite while still on the phone. Once he picks a time, confirm and stop selling.

branches.label: Wants to check his calendar first

book_meeting_follow.label: PIN DOWN THE FOLLOW-UP
book_meeting_follow.say: Totally — tell you what, I'll shoot you an invite for Thursday at 10 AM Pacific and if that doesn't work, just throw me a time that does. What's the best email for you — is it jim at tahoegetaways dot com?
book_meeting_follow.note: Don't let it float. Send a specific invite so there's something concrete in his inbox. Confirm his email address while you have him.

branches.label: He confirms email or agrees to the invite
He says just send to the general inbox

meeting_confirmed.label: MEETING BOOKED — WRAP UP
meeting_confirmed.say: Perfect, that's locked in. Really appreciate you taking my call, Jim — I know cold calls aren't exactly the highlight of anyone's day. Talk to you then.
meeting_confirmed.note: STOP SELLING. You got what you came for. Be grateful, be brief, hang up. Don't introduce anything new that could unravel the commitment.

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it — I should've assumed you'd be all set. Otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so no one from my team cold calls you again — is it that this isn't really a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls? Because honestly I wouldn't blame you.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first, then split the objection. 'Not focused on it' opens the door to timing and the test drive. 'Hate cold calls' lets you acknowledge the medium and redirect to value.

branches.label: Not focused on it right now

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — ALREADY HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That totally makes sense — with 200-plus properties you'd have to have something in place already. Just so I know — is it that you're fully covered and happy with how inspections are working, or is it more that switching anything right now would be a headache?
objection_have_process.note: Split the objection. 'Happy' means you need to find a gap or plant a seed. 'Headache to switch' is your opening — RapidEye requires zero workflow change. That's the wedge.

branches.label: He names a specific tool they use

no_workflow_change.label: NO WORKFLOW CHANGE — KEY DIFFERENTIATOR
no_workflow_change.say: Yeah that's actually why I brought it up — the whole point is that nothing changes for your team. Your cleaners keep taking photos exactly like they do now, and our AI just runs in the background analyzing them. No new app, no new checklist, no retraining. It's literally invisible to your field team. That's usually the thing that gets people to at least take a look.
no_workflow_change.note: This is your strongest counter to the 'switching is a pain' objection. Zero workflow change is RapidEye's wedge. Transition to the CTA.

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it — nowadays it's hard enough to keep the tools you already have, let alone buy something new. And I'm definitely not trying to sell you anything today. But just so I can flag this — is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything new has to go through a gauntlet to get approved?
objection_no_budget.note: Agree first. Split the objection. 'Locked' = timing issue, ask about next budget cycle. 'Gauntlet' = process issue, offer to arm him with materials that make the internal case easier.

test_drive_pitch.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
test_drive_pitch.say: Look — you're probably not buying anything off a cold call, and I totally respect that. But the managers who end up working with us are always the ones who saw it early and kicked the tires when there was no pressure. Would you be open to just taking a look — no commitment, no follow-up sequence if you hate it — just so you know what's out there? If nothing else, I can walk you through what a few other Tahoe operators are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas.
test_drive_pitch.note: This is your fallback CTA for anyone who's objected but is still on the line. Sell the test drive, not the product. The 'other Tahoe operators' line adds competitive pressure without naming names. If he says yes, book immediately.

objection_send_email.label: OBJECTION — SEND ME AN EMAIL
objection_send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll get something over to you today. One quick question so it's not just another generic pitch deck — what would be most relevant to you? Is it more the operational side, how it actually works with your turnover photos, or is it the business case — what it means for damage recovery and owner retention?
objection_send_email.note: Accept the email request but ask one question to tailor the follow-up. Whatever he answers tells you what he cares about. Then confirm his email and set a follow-up expectation.

branches.label: He tells you what to include

email_close.label: CLOSE ON EMAIL PLUS TIME
email_close.say: Got it — I'll keep it short and relevant. What's the best email for you — is it jim at tahoegetaways dot com? And if I don't hear back by Friday, would it be cool if I followed up once just to make sure it landed?
email_close.note: Confirm his email address. Set the expectation for one follow-up touchpoint so you have permission to call again. Getting a confirmed email is a win even if the meeting doesn't happen today.

branches.label: He confirms email and agrees to follow-up
He gives email but says don't call

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL — WHO HANDLES THIS
referral_ask.say: Totally fair — and honestly, this might not even be your plate to deal with day-to-day. Who on your team typically owns the inspection and turnover workflow? Is that more of an ops function for you guys?
referral_ask.note: You know Abigail Shea is Operations Manager, Michael Kruck is Project Management Specialist, and Sophie Katz is Guest Experience Manager. Don't name-drop yet — let him volunteer a name first. If he says 'ops team' but no name, then prompt with Abigail.

branches.label: He gives a name or title
He says 'ops team' but no specific name
He says he handles it himself
He's not willing to refer anyone

referral_prompt_name.label: REFERRAL — PROMPT FOR NAME
referral_prompt_name.say: Got it — would that be someone like Abigail on the ops side? I just want to make sure I reach the right person so it actually lands and doesn't get lost in a general inbox.
referral_prompt_name.note: Name-drop Abigail Shea naturally. This shows you've done homework without being creepy. If he confirms or corrects you, you've got your next call target with a warm intro.

branches.label: He confirms Abigail or gives her info

referral_get_name.label: REFERRAL — LOCK IT IN
referral_get_name.say: Perfect — I really appreciate that. I'll put something tailored together for them so it's not just a random cold outreach. Would it be cool if I mentioned you pointed me their way? That way it doesn't come totally out of left field for them.
referral_get_name.note: Get permission to use Jim's name as a referral. This transforms your next call from cold to warm. If he says yes, you now have a founder-level referral into their ops team.

branches.label: He's fine with you using his name
He'd rather you didn't use his name

referral_confirmed.label: REFERRAL CONFIRMED — WRAP UP
referral_confirmed.say: Really appreciate it, Jim. I'll keep it short with them. And if it does end up being relevant, maybe we loop you in down the line. Thanks for your time — enjoy the rest of your day.
referral_confirmed.note: You got a referral. That's a win. End gracefully and don't try to re-pitch Jim. Note who he referred you to and reach out within 24 hours while it's fresh.

referral_last_shot.label: LAST SHOT — REFERRAL BEFORE EXIT
referral_last_shot.say: Totally respect that. Last thing — is there anyone on your ops side who might want to see this? I know it's not necessarily a founder-level decision on day one, and I don't want to waste your time if someone else owns that workflow.
referral_last_shot.note: This is your last attempt to get value from the call before exiting. Even if Jim isn't buying, getting pointed to Abigail Shea or another ops contact makes this call worthwhile.

branches.label: He gives a name or suggests someone

end_graceful.label: END GRACEFULLY
end_graceful.say: Totally understand, Jim. If anything changes on your end, I'm easy to find. Appreciate you taking my call.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. Stay professional. Log the call and the outcome. You may come back via email or try again in 3-6 months with new traction or a referral from another Tahoe manager.
